bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Irving S. Wright, July 31, 1943

div1.p: Hench thanks Wright for the newspaper clipping about England and he discusses England's association with the yellow experiments. Hench had planned to pose some personal questions to Wright, but the war has interfered with his yellow fever research.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Irving S. Wright, July 31, 1943
div1.opener:
STATION HOSPITAL
CAMP CARSON COLORADO
31 July 43
Lt Col Irving S. Wright
Chief of Medical Service
Army and Navy General Hospital
Hot Springs, Arkansas
My dear Irv:
div1.p:
I received your letter of July 26 and also that of
July 28. I enclose a film of the three of us. You might
be able to get a nice little enlargement out of it. Thank
you especially for sending me the clipping from the New
York times about Colonel England. He actually was one of
the original human guinea pigs and deserves all the credit
in the world. I at one time had his address and wrote to
him but my letter was returned to me, address unknown. About
a year ago I got his address and have been planning to write
him ever since. I wanted to ask him several important ques-
tions which he alone could answer, but the war has interfered
greatly with my yellow fever hobby and I never got around to
it. I was therefore just sick to hear of his death. Never-
theless, I am glad to have the clipping as I may be able
to write his relatives.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. HENCH
Lieut Colonel, MC PSH:rw
